label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, September 30, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a concert she attended with friends in London, England, the atmosphere of the city during the war, and informing him of clothes and food shortages.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a concert she attended with friends in London, England, the atmosphere of the city during the war, and informing him of clothes and food shortages.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
13
Sept. 30th '43
Dear Sidney,
Last night I went to a concert at Albert Hall with
Avie, Bobbie Strawbridge [and] Mary Marlborough . It was
a real "sing fest." 200 American colored soldiers and
Roland Hayes - when they sand the spirtuals-
"Deep River, "I got a Sister Over There," "The Lord
is going to Lay his Cold Icy Hands on My."
[and] "I Want to Die Easy", etc. etc. it
was really wonderful!! All those wonderful
queer low [and] high notes with breaks in
the middle,and a conductor that was
lose jointed [and] so graceful it was fascinating.
It was right up my alley [and] you would
have loved it too. The 200 men evidently
had been told they could n't sway [and] tap
their feet, but I assure you before the
end of the program they were all
full of rythm, [and] swayed about as
they they were singing around the
fire under the oaks at Medway -
They did n't want to stop at all
when it was time for "God Save the
King "- That is really singing 
at its best for they did n't try anything
[End Page 1]
2
highbrow. I felt old Sam our tractor
man might have been in the group
but I was too far away to recognize
the faces-
The hall was so draughty that although 
I had on a sweater , coat [and] over coat
I could feel my cold increasing in
leaps [and] bounds. We had supper after
wards at Claridges as by this time it was
just 9 P.M. The shows all start at 8.45 .
It is a good system I think because it gets
one to bed at a reasonable hour -
The 
The streets are so black that even
the oldest inhabitant loses the way -
I nearly always fall flat on my face
where I get through the revolving doors.
The hotel is crouded all the time -
High ranking officers jam the lobby -
People come [and] go [and] there is fearful
activity every minute - I am sure
when I finally get into my flat
it will seem very peaceful [and] welcome.
Mary Marlborough is very smart in her dark
blue uniform with gold shoulder boards.
She looks like an Admiral but is really
head of the Red Cross though out the country
districts. Blendan [?] is filled with officers
[End Page 2]
3
[and] she lives in one wing .
The streets are full of girls in uniform
[and] I must say they are a grim looking
lot - cotton stockings , low shoes, toting
brief cases , and looking terribly masculine.
The U.S. gals don't look too chic
either . Think they picked a poor looking
bunch to send over as I have n't seen
any beauties - That goes for the Red Cross
gals too. Clothes coupons are scarce
- it takes a lot to buy anything - consequently
people look a little run down at the heel
which is only natural. getting the war
won is the jobs - [and] that's all any body
cares about - Believe me its a
better atmosphere than Washington -
here every one works, [and] I see less
signs of "power" [and] "promotions" [and]
more real work [and] earnestness. People
look tired - may be a little stale =
I don't wonder. as far as food [and] 
health goes it could [n't] be better . People
are well fed [and] look more spry [and]
keen than they ever have [even the 'tired'] - I am
told country children have never has
more balanced diets.
I hope you are getting my letters darling
[and] that they won't take too long -
Lots of love my darling-
Your- Gertie.
[End Page 3]
